Waveland Elementary students Benjamin Bloss and Maddalena Saltalamacchia are among the top winners of the 2019 Promote the Vote contest. They were honored March 4 at the State Capitol, where their entries are on display.

Benjamin won first place in the state in the K- 2 grades category and received $100 along with the honor. Maddalena won second place and received $75. Art teacher Dale Pohl received $100 for the art program at Waveland Elementary.

Secretary of State Michael Watson presented Benjamin and Maddalena with certificates recognizing their achievement in the statewide contest. This year’s art contest theme was “Proud to be a Mississippian.”

“In class, we talked about all the things that are special to us about Mississippi and what makes it “My Mississippi,” said Mrs. Pohl. A state farmer gave the class some Mississippi grown cotton to view and touch, and the students studied state wildlife and images from the Hill Country, the Delta and the Coast to prepare for the contest.

post_text:
Bay High hosted a Civil Rights symposium on the segregation era in Bay St. Louis and Waveland on Friday as part of Black History Month. The program was coordinated by History teacher Jeremy Turcotte and dedicated to the memory of longtime teacher and principal Roger James.

Greg Barabino, president of the Hancock County NAACP chapter and a Bay High graduate, outlined the history of the organization and its accomplishments on the national and local levels. Jeffrey Reed, a pastor and Bay St. Louis councilman, and Clarence Harris, a community activist, shared their memories as students in the local schools and retired teachers Clementine Williams and Rose Lewis talked about their experiences and lessons from the era. Mr. Harris, who attended Valena C. Jones, encouraged the students “to be fair to everybody and never have hate in your heart.” Pastor Reed, a Bay High graduate, shared a lesson he taught his daughters: “It’s not how other people treat you, it’s how you treat other people.”
